text: Hi, I'm facing this problem: I need to load 600 files in live-trading, each of them contains a row of a DF, and concat them into a Pandas DataFrame for analysis. Anyone knows what would be a fast file format to do this? I've tried with .parquet which takes 0.03 secs/file but I need something faster...

elements.text: Hi, I'm facing this problem: I need to load 600 files in live-trading, each of them contains a row of a DF, and concat them into a Pandas DataFrame for analysis. Anyone knows what would be a fast file format to do this? I've tried with .parquet which takes 0.03 secs/file but I need something faster...

text: Reading the file with `fastparquet.ParquetFile()` is very fast but I cannot find a way of concatenating the files without converting to Pandas (which is slow...)

elements.text: Reading the file with
fastparquet.ParquetFile()
is very fast but I cannot find a way of concatenating the files without converting to Pandas (which is slow...)

text:
A few questions:

1. Why does it need to be fast? Can't you read them all on startup and be done with it?
2. Do they need to be separate files? Reading one file will probably be quicker
3. Do you actually need the end result to be a DataFrame? As you say, pandas performance is sometimes not the best

elements.text: A few questions:
Why does it need to be fast? Can't you read them all on startup and be done with it?
Do they need to be separate files? Reading one file will probably be quicker
Do you actually need the end result to be a DataFrame? As you say, pandas performance is sometimes not the best

text:
1. Yes, I read them on startup but I have multiple factors and each factor has 600 files so I would like it to be as fast as possible.
2. I save them as separate real-time files.
3. It would be very convenient, the rest of my infra supports Pandas

elements.text: Yes, I read them on startup but I have multiple factors and each factor has 600 files so I would like it to be as fast as possible.
I save them as separate real-time files.
It would be very convenient, the rest of my infra supports Pandas

text: How about using multiprocessing to read the files in parallel? Might save you a bit of time. Concatenation at the end will still be a bottleneck though

elements.text: How about using multiprocessing to read the files in parallel? Might save you a bit of time. Concatenation at the end will still be a bottleneck though

text: Maybe just try pickle? I'm using feather (from pyarrow) for fast io with small data frames, but if you're python only I think pickle is pretty fast.

elements.text: Maybe just try pickle? I'm using feather (from pyarrow) for fast io with small data frames, but if you're python only I think pickle is pretty fast.

text: Honestly I think you need to solve this by outputting the data differently in the first place. For example, stick it into rows in a database table

elements.text: Honestly I think you need to solve this by outputting the data differently in the first place. For example, stick it into rows in a database table

text:
I get "I want to avoid using databases" but this really does sound like it's begging for a sqlite database.

Write to that instead of flat files and get sub millisecond reads when you need the data back.

(disclaimer, I'm a recent convert having recently used this approach to solve a processing bottleneck in one of my strategies).

elements.text:
I get "I want to avoid using databases" but this really does sound like it's begging for a sqlite database.

Write to that instead of flat files and get sub millisecond reads when you need the data back.

(disclaimer, I'm a recent convert having recently used this approach to solve a processing bottleneck in one of my strategies).

text: Why not store them all in memory at start up ? If there are too many events (eg uk dogs) then just load it a minute or so before needed instead. A dictionary with each factor as an entry with 600 rows won't take up that much space and much quicker to then analyse and "walk" the data as needed.

elements.text: Why not store them all in memory at start up ? If there are too many events (eg uk dogs) then just load it a minute or so before needed instead. A dictionary with each factor as an entry with 600 rows won't take up that much space and much quicker to then analyse and "walk" the data as needed.

text: Sounds like trying to solve a design issue with brute force. I'd question the need for 600 files by the sniff test if nothing else. And/or I agree with <@U9JHLMZB4>, wanting to avoid a database doesn't trump needing one.

elements.text: Sounds like trying to solve a design issue with brute force. I'd question the need for 600 files by the sniff test if nothing else. And/or I agree with
, wanting to avoid a database doesn't trump needing one.
